text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why the man on the 10th floor takes the elevator down every morning and then, in the evening, goes to the 7th floor by elevator and walks up three floors.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
Hmm, that's a bit puzzling.
Let me break it down.
First, let's consider his daily routine.
He lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor (which is the 1st floor) to go to work.
That makes sense because taking the elevator down is faster than walking down 10 floors, especially if the building is tall.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the remaining three floors to his apartment.
So, why doesn't he just take the elevator all the way to the 10th floor every evening? Well, maybe it's about the effort or time.
Taking the elevator up only to the 7th floor and then walking up three floors might be easier or quicker than going all the way up to 10.
But then, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
So, why the change on rainy days? Maybe because on rainy days, he doesn't want to get his clothes wet by walking up the stairs.
Walking three floors in the rain could mean getting wet, which he avoids by taking the elevator all the way up.
Alternatively, perhaps there's something about the elevator itself.
Maybe on rainy days, the elevator is faster or more reliable, so he prefers it.
Or maybe the elevator is out of service, but that doesn't make sense because he uses it every morning and evening.
Wait, no, the problem says he takes the elevator every morning and evening except on rainy days when he takes it all the way up.
Wait, maybe it's about the time.
If he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor, he can walk up three floors, which might take less time than waiting for the elevator to go all the way up.
But on rainy days, he might prefer the convenience of the elevator to avoid getting wet.
Another angle: maybe the building has a policy or rule about using the elevator.
For example, perhaps after a certain time, the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor, so he has to walk up the rest.
But that might not explain why he takes the elevator all the way on rainy days.
Wait, perhaps the man works in an area where it's raining in the evenings, so he prefers not to be outside in the rain.
So, he takes the elevator all the way up to his apartment to avoid getting wet.
That makes sense because if it's raining, he doesn't want to be walking up the stairs, which are probably outside or exposed.

So, putting it all together, during normal days, he takes the elevator down in the morning and up to the 7th floor in the evening, then walks up three floors because it's quicker or he doesn't mind the walk.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to avoid getting wet while walking the stairs.
I think that's the main reason.
He's trying to avoid getting wet on rainy days by using the elevator instead of walking up the stairs.

</think>

The man takes the elevator down every morning because it's faster than walking.
In the evening, he goes to the 7th floor by elevator and walks up three floors, perhaps because it's quicker or he prefers it.
On rainy days, he uses the elevator all the way to avoid getting wet while walking up the stairs.
